description: From cook +‎ -ing. The noun and adjective follow from the verb. The use of the word cooking to describe cheap bitter was popularised by the title character of the BBC sitcom Oh No, It’s Selwyn Froggitt (1974-1978).

examples: I filled the cooking pot with water
I put a lid on the cooking pan
The project took a few days to gain momentum, but by the end of the week, things were really cooking.

entries.meaning: (of an alcoholic drink) Cheap; better suited for use in recipes than drinking.
(uncountable) The process of preparing food by using heat.
(countable, rare) An instance of preparing food by using heat.

definitionGroups.group: The result of preparing food by using heat.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) One's ability to prepare food; cookery.
examples: My cooking isn't very good. I don't have any idea how to prepare a good meal.
I missed my mum's cooking while I was at university.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The style or genre of food preparation.
examples: What you've produced is a perfect example of authentic Chinese cooking.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The cheapest available beer for sale in a public house; cooking bitter or cooking lager.
